data2histogram.py - histogram data in a table¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id$
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

Purpose¶

This script computes histograms over one or more columns of a table.

Usage¶

Example:

python data2histogram.py --help

Type:

python data2histogram.py --help

for command line help.

Command line options¶

Usage: data2histogram.py [options]

Options:
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --no-usage            output help without usage information
  -r RANGE, --range=RANGE
                        range to calculate histogram for.
  -b BIN_SIZE, --bin-size=BIN_SIZE
                        bin size.
  -i, --titles          use supplied column titles.
  --no-null             do not output null values
  --no-titles           no column titles given.
  -c COLUMNS, --columns=COLUMNS
                        columns to take for calculating histograms.
  --min-data=MIN_DATA   minimum amount of data required, if less data, then
                        the histogram will be empty [default=1].
  --min-value=MIN_VALUE
                        minimum value for histogram.
  --max-value=MAX_VALUE
                        maximum value for histogram.
  --no-empty-bins       do not display empty bins.
  --with-empty-bins     display empty bins.
  --normalize           normalize histogram.
  --cumulative          calculate cumulative histogram.
  --reverse-cumulative  calculate reverse cumulative histogram.
  --headers=HEADERS     use the following headers.
  --ignore-out-of-range
                        ignore values that are out of range (as opposed to
                        truncating them to range border.
  --missing=MISSING_VALUE
                        entry for missing values [na].
  --dynamic-bins        each value constitutes its own bin.
  --on-the-fly          on the fly computation of histograms. Requires setting
                        of min-value, max-value and bin_size.
  -v LOGLEVEL, --verbose=LOGLEVEL
                        loglevel [1]. The higher, the more output.
  --timeit=TIMEIT_FILE  store timeing information in file [none].
  --timeit-name=TIMEIT_NAME
                        name in timing file for this class of jobs [all].
  --timeit-header       add header for timing information [none].
  --random-seed=RANDOM_SEED
                        random seed to initialize number generator with
                        [none].
  -I FILE, --stdin=FILE
                        file to read stdin from [default = stdin].
  -L FILE, --log=FILE   file with logging information [default = stdout].
  -E FILE, --error=FILE
                        file with error information [default = stderr].
  -S FILE, --stdout=FILE
                        file where output is to go [default = stdout].
